Title: Subjective wellbeing among university students & physical activity patterns

Reasoning for "Population Age": The study focuses on college students, who are typically adults (18+). This meets the criterion for a population of adults aged 18 or older.
Reasoning for "Activity Transition": The study doesn't measure participants transitioning from sedentary to active lifestyles. It simply compares existing activity levels. This fails to meet the criterion for measuring baseline activity levels and examining participants transitioning from a sedentary to more active lifestyle.
Reasoning for "Population Activity Level: The study includes both active and sedentary college students from the general population, not elite athletes. This meets the criterion for a population from the general or sedentary population.
Reasoning for "Intervention Type": This is not an intervention study - it's an observational study measuring existing physical activity levels using IPAQ. This fails to meet the criterion for examining a physical activity intervention.
Reasoning for "Intervention Duration": No intervention duration is mentioned as this is not an intervention study. This fails to meet the criterion for an intervention duration of at least 4 weeks.
Reasoning for "Intervention Frequency": This is not an intervention study - it's an observational study comparing existing activity levels. It doesn't examine sustained behavior change. This fails to meet the criterion for examining sustained behavior change.
Reasoning for "Outcome Measures": The study uses the Subjective Well-being scale (SUBI) by Nagpal & Sell (1985), which is a validated instrument measuring wellbeing. This meets the criterion for measuring life satisfaction, wellbeing, or quality of life using validated instruments.
Reasoning for "Study Design": The study appears to be a cross-sectional observational study comparing active vs inactive students, not an interventional or longitudinal study. This fails to meet the criterion for an interventional or longitudinal observational study design.
Reasoning for "Screening judgement": A cross-sectional observational study examining physical activity and subjective well-being among college students, which fails to meet key screening criteria related to intervention design, behavior change, and sustained activity transitions. While the study uses validated instruments and includes an appropriate adult population, its fundamental research approach does not align with the required methodological standards for inclusion.

Reasoning for "Population Age": The study focuses on adults aged 60 years or older, which meets the criterion for all study participants being adults (aged 18 or older).
Reasoning for "Activity Transition": While the paper discusses physical activity in older adults, it does not specifically measure baseline activity levels or track transitions from sedentary to active lifestyles, which does not meet the criterion for measuring baseline activity levels and examining participants transitioning from a sedentary to more active lifestyle.
Reasoning for "Population Activity Level: The study appears to focus on the general older adult population, not exclusively elite athletes, which would meet the criterion for the study participants being from the general or sedentary population.
Reasoning for "Intervention Type": This is not an intervention study, but rather a qualitative synthesis of factors influencing physical activity, which does not meet the criterion for examining a physical activity intervention.
Reasoning for "Intervention Duration": No specific intervention duration is examined as this is not an intervention study, which does not meet the criterion for an intervention duration of at least 4 weeks.
Reasoning for "Intervention Frequency": The paper does not examine specific interventions or their frequency. It's a qualitative synthesis of factors influencing physical activity, which does not meet the criterion for examining sustained behavior change.
Reasoning for "Outcome Measures": While the paper discusses life satisfaction and sense of purpose, it does not measure these using validated instruments. Instead, it synthesizes qualitative findings about these concepts, which does not meet the criterion for measuring life satisfaction, wellbeing, or quality of life using validated instruments.
Reasoning for "Study Design": The study design was a qualitative meta-ethnography synthesizing other studies, not an interventional or longitudinal observational study itself. This does not meet the criterion for an interventional or longitudinal observational study design.
Reasoning for "Screening judgement": This qualitative meta-ethnography fails to meet most screening criteria, particularly those related to study design, intervention characteristics, and outcome measurement. While the study focuses on older adults and their physical activity experiences, it lacks the structured intervention and validated measurement approaches required by the screening criteria. Consequently, the paper would likely be excluded from the systematic review.

Title: Adopting an active lifestyle during adulthood and health-related quality of life: the Doetinchem Cohort Study.
Authors: S. H. V. Oostrom, Henriette A. Smit, G. Wendel-Vos, M. Visser, W. Verschuren, H. Susan, J. Picavet
Reasoning for "Population Age": The participants were adults aged 26-70 years (mean 47.4), all above 18 years, meeting the criteria for a population of adults (aged 18 or older).
Reasoning for "Activity Transition": The study explicitly examined participants transitioning from inactive to active lifestyles ("became physically active") and measured baseline activity levels, meeting the criteria for measuring baseline activity levels and examining participants transitioning from a sedentary to more active lifestyle.
Reasoning for "Population Activity Level: The study included participants from the general population, including both active and inactive individuals, not exclusively elite athletes or highly active individuals, meeting the criteria for a population from the general or sedentary population.
Reasoning for "Intervention Type": While the study examined physical activity, it's not clear if this was an intervention study or purely observational. The abstract doesn't specify if participants were assigned to activity programs or if this was natural behavior change.
Reasoning for "Intervention Duration": The study duration was 10 years, well exceeding the 4-week minimum requirement for intervention duration.
Reasoning for "Intervention Frequency": The study examined sustained behavior change over 10 years, not just acute effects of single exercise sessions, meeting the criteria for examining sustained behavior change.
Reasoning for "Outcome Measures": The study measured health-related quality of life using a survey similar to the 36-Item Short-Form Health Survey, which is a validated instrument, meeting the criteria for measuring life satisfaction, wellbeing, or quality of life using validated instruments.
Reasoning for "Study Design": The study design was a longitudinal observational study that followed participants over 10 years with multiple measurements, which meets the criteria for an interventional or longitudinal observational study design.
Reasoning for "Screening judgement": A longitudinal observational study examining physical activity transitions among adults aged 26-70, measuring health-related quality of life using validated instruments over a 10-year period. The research comprehensively tracked participants' activity levels, capturing transitions from sedentary to active lifestyles while assessing multiple dimensions of wellbeing. With robust methodology and a representative population sample, the study provides insights into sustained physical activity's impact on quality of life.

Reasoning for "Population Age": The study explicitly included adults with a mean age of 42.1 ± 13.3 years.
Reasoning for "Activity Transition": The study did not measure baseline activity levels or examine transitions from sedentary to active lifestyles. It only looked at current activity levels and wellbeing.
Reasoning for "Population Activity Level: The study examined the general European adult population, not elite athletes.
Reasoning for "Intervention Type": This was not an intervention study, as it examined physical activity but did not implement or test any physical activity intervention.
Reasoning for "Intervention Duration": As a cross-sectional study, there was no intervention duration to assess.
Reasoning for "Intervention Frequency": This was not an intervention study, as it examined associations between physical activity and wellbeing at a single time point, rather than sustained behavior change.
Reasoning for "Outcome Measures": The study measured multiple dimensions of self-rated wellbeing using what appears to be a structured assessment, including evaluative wellbeing, emotional wellbeing, functioning, vitality, community wellbeing, and supportive wellbeing.
Reasoning for "Study Design": The study design was explicitly described as a "cross-sectional study", which does not meet the criteria of being interventional or longitudinal observational.
Reasoning for "Screening judgement": A cross-sectional study examining physical activity and wellbeing among European adults fails to meet key screening criteria, particularly around intervention design and sustained behavior change. While the research includes appropriate population demographics and measures wellbeing comprehensively, its single-time-point methodology disqualifies it from meeting the systematic review's requirements for interventional or longitudinal research.

Reasoning for "Screening judgement": This cross-sectional study examining physical activity and happiness among older adults in low- and middle-income countries fails to meet key screening criteria, particularly around study design and intervention requirements.
